ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I recommend this course even to other students in the astronomy department. It was a bit of a "culture shock" to get back into mathematical formalisms and Lagrangian mechanics, but I learned a lot from this course.

Physics 538 is a very good class if you are interested in astrophysics or general relativity. Be warned that it does require some high-level mathematics, so having some familiarity with manifolds would be wise before taking the course.
This a rigorous well-paced and advanced introduction to general relativity and cosmology.

A freshman could take this class, provided he has a decent background in covariant electrodynamics with gauge and is familiar with the language of differential geometry. Good motivation and a genuine interest in the material is a must before taking the class, as well as being able to self-study and lean the material on your own so that you may keep up with and take more out of the lectures. It is highly recommended to have multiple reference texts on GR with you as you go through this course.
I would recommend it to people interested in studying astrophysics as it goes deeper into the things that comes up a lot when talking about curvature, expansion, etc.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: As someone intending to work on black holes, this class was indispensable.

For a serious physicist, knowing how to work with symmetries, killing fields, and gauges is a must, and so this class is an excellent preparation for both quantum and classical field theories. Especially considering the modern fascination with inflation, this class allows the student to understand with some clarity the goings-on in the forefront of gravitational physics. One setback is that Einstein's equations are not derived, and so self-study from alternate texts is especially recommended for understanding.
